item.title: Senate Health Care Bill Revisions Released In Attempt To Appease GOP Critics
item.description: July 13, 2017 - In need of more votes, Senate leaders have produced a new bill that offers billions more in opioid epidemic assistance but it keeps proposed cuts to Medicaid spending.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - In need of more votes, Senate leaders have produced a new bill that offers billions more in opioid epidemic assistance but it keeps proposed cuts to Medicaid spending. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/13/537040114/senate-gop-releases-revised-affordable-care-act-repeal-and-replace-plan

item.title: 'Extreme' Opioid Use And Doctor Shopping Still Plague Medicare
item.description: July 13, 2017 - One-third of all Medicare recipients were prescribed opioids last year, the HHS inspector general says, with more than half a million getting high doses for at least three months.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - One-third of all Medicare recipients were prescribed opioids last year, the HHS inspector general says, with more than half a million getting high doses for at least three months. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/13/536873912/extreme-opioid-use-and-doctor-shopping-still-plague-medicare

item.title: Mobile App Designed To Prevent Pregnancy Gets EU Approval
item.description: July 13, 2017 - For the first time, a medically approved birth control app has been certified as a method of contraception. It relies on math, an algorithm and a woman's body temperature to determine fertility.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - For the first time, a medically approved birth control app has been certified as a method of contraception. It relies on math, an algorithm and a woman's body temperature to determine fertility. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/13/536974741/mobile-app-designed-to-prevent-pregnancy-gets-e-u-approval

item.title: 'Living Drug' That Fights Cancer By Harnessing Immune System Clears Key Hurdle
item.description: July 12, 2017 - An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommends the agency, for the first time, approve a new kind of treatment that uses genetically modified immune cells to attack cancer cells.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommends the agency, for the first time, approve a new kind of treatment that uses genetically modified immune cells to attack cancer cells. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536812206/living-drug-that-fights-cancer-by-harnessing-the-immune-system-clears-key-hurdle

item.title: Health Insurers Try Paying More Up Front To Pay Less Later
item.description: July 12, 2017 - Some businesses are keeping costs down for workers by removing deductibles for supplies needed to manage diabetes and other chronic conditions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - Some businesses are keeping costs down for workers by removing deductibles for supplies needed to manage diabetes and other chronic conditions. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536830635/health-insurers-try-paying-more-up-front-to-pay-less-later

item.title: Democrats Eager To Work On Bipartisan Health Care Effort If GOP Bill Fails
item.description: July 12, 2017 - Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell warned his GOP colleagues they may have to work with Democrats if they can't pass their own health care bill. NPR takes a look at what Democrats would want if that happened.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell warned his GOP colleagues they may have to work with Democrats if they can't pass their own health care bill. NPR takes a look at what Democrats would want if that happened. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/12/536887846/democrats-eager-to-work-on-bipartisan-health-care-effort-if-gop-bill-fails

item.title: Michigan Laws Will Increase Penalties For Performing Female Genital Mutilation
item.description: July 12, 2017 - The laws were spurred by the criminal case of an emergency room doctor charged with performing the procedure on multiple girls in suburban Detroit. The United States banned the practice in 1996.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - The laws were spurred by the criminal case of an emergency room doctor charged with performing the procedure on multiple girls in suburban Detroit. The United States banned the practice in 1996. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/12/536863961/michigan-laws-will-increase-penalties-for-performing-female-genital-mutilation

item.title: More People Are Making Mistakes With Medicines At Home
item.description: July 12, 2017 - A study analyzing data from poison control centers finds that the rate of serious medication errors outside health care settings doubled between 2000 and 2012.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - A study analyzing data from poison control centers finds that the rate of serious medication errors outside health care settings doubled between 2000 and 2012. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536519077/took-the-wrong-medicine-by-mistake-study-finds-such-errors-are-on-the-rise

item.title: Senate's Health Bill Would Make Life Easier For Some Small Businesses
item.description: July 12, 2017 - Some small businesses buy their health plans through trade associations. The GOP health bills would make those cheaper. But that could also make employer-based insurance more expensive for others.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - Some small businesses buy their health plans through trade associations. The GOP health bills would make those cheaper. But that could also make employer-based insurance more expensive for others. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/12/536734314/senates-health-bill-would-ease-rules-for-some-small-business-health-plans

item.title: Video: Japan Created Easy-To-Swallow Foods To Prevent Senior Choking Deaths
item.description: July 12, 2017 - In NPR's Elise Tries series, correspondent Elise Hu tries out different experiences in East Asia. In rapidly aging Japan, an edible innovation is helping seniors enjoy meals without fear of choking.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 12, 2017 - In NPR's Elise Tries series, correspondent Elise Hu tries out different experiences in East Asia. In rapidly aging Japan, an edible innovation is helping seniors enjoy meals without fear of choking. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/07/12/532716164/video-japan-created-easy-to-swallow-foods-to-prevent-senior-choking-deaths

item.title: Delaying August Recess, Senate Republicans To Release Updated Health Care Bill
item.description: July 11, 2017 - The new bill will be released Thursday and could come to the floor next week. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has also delayed the Senate's August recess by two weeks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - The new bill will be released Thursday and could come to the floor next week. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has also delayed the Senate's August recess by two weeks. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/11/536704485/delaying-august-recess-senate-republicans-to-release-updated-health-care-bill

item.title: Senate Republicans Press Forward Despite Sharp Division On Health Care Bill
item.description: July 11, 2017 - Senate Republicans regrouped on Tuesday, as they tried to forge a path forward on health care legislation. The White House and GOP leaders pressed forward with the goal of voting next week.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - Senate Republicans regrouped on Tuesday, as they tried to forge a path forward on health care legislation. The White House and GOP leaders pressed forward with the goal of voting next week. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/11/536699776/senate-republicans-press-forward-despite-sharp-division-on-health-care-bill

item.title: In Texas, People With Mental Illness Are Finding Work Helping Peers
item.description: July 11, 2017 - Giving people who have serious mental illness peer support has proved so helpful that some states are starting to pay these peer specialists to bridge the gap when there aren't enough professionals.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - Giving people who have serious mental illness peer support has proved so helpful that some states are starting to pay these peer specialists to bridge the gap when there aren't enough professionals. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/11/536501069/in-texas-people-with-mental-illness-are-finding-work-helping-peers

item.title: What This Teen Mom Wishes She'd Known Before She Got Pregnant
item.description: July 11, 2017 - She was ashamed to be seen buying condoms. She didn't dare ask her mother for advice. So how can Uganda bring down its high rate of teen pregnancy?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - She was ashamed to be seen buying condoms. She didn't dare ask her mother for advice. So how can Uganda bring down its high rate of teen pregnancy? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/11/536428219/what-this-teen-mom-wishes-shed-known-before-she-got-pregnant

item.title: Credit Agencies To Ease Up On Medical Debt Reporting
item.description: July 11, 2017 - Starting in September, the three main credit agencies will wait 180 days before including medical debt on a credit report, giving consumers time to resolve disputes with insurers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 11, 2017 - Starting in September, the three main credit agencies will wait 180 days before including medical debt on a credit report, giving consumers time to resolve disputes with insurers. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/11/536501809/credit-agencies-to-ease-up-on-medical-debt-reporting
